text.p: The following are the main stories from Thursday morning's German newspapers:
- Tensions increase in Bonn coalition government, focal point of dispute between CSU and FDP is planned tax reform. Polemic and warnings mark debate.
- Proposal from CDU party members to raise retirement age to 67 from 65 run into widespread criticism, both from opposition and from within CDU.

- Interior Minister Manfred Kanther opposed to dismantling professional civil service system. He rejects proposals to lift civil servant status for everyone but police officers, justic authority and army.
- SPD wants to help finances of health insurance system by raising the contributions high-income earners pay into system.
- Finance Minister Theo Waigel says there will be additional nine billion mark hole in 1996 budget
- Bavaria deports first Bosnian refugee, a 29-year-old criminal who was convicted on several counts of sexual coercion, theft and drinkenness.
- IG Metall metalworkers union has prepared tough stance for negotiations with employers over planned cuts in sick pay
- German army preparing to send 1,500-man peacekeeping force to Bosnia in 1997
